The ‘uninominal vote’ was thought to make representation between the citizen and the elected parliamentarian more effective, mainly in the citizens’ interest. In reality, this electoral system has led neither to an increase in the feeling of responsibility on the part of the politicians to their electorate, nor to a stronger civic spirit on the part of the electorate. It was overlooked that Romanian political life depended on other factors, related to historical context, tradition, history, dominant political culture, social structure, etc.: ‘the election system can be, at most, a premise, which is necessary, but not sufficient for the change of a political reality considered unsatisfactory’ (Buti, 2009: 41). The modernity of a new electoral system thus remains an inclination towards a desideratum that has not yet been achieved.

Another example which explains tendential modernity is the adoption of political strategies from other countries, great significance being attributed at present to the Contract with Romania, a programmatic document elaborated by the Romanian Democratic Convention (RDC) in 1996, based mainly on the election manifesto of the US Republican Party (Contract with America). In this document, the RDC promised the electorate that, within 200 days from the time they became the leading party, they would pass laws to improve the economic and social situation of the country. It must be remembered that the RDC was sending a message of wide support offered by the Western democracies and, as a consequence, they insisted on inviting many foreign investors to Romania. It was estimated that Romania would benefit from 60 billion dollars in investments, and the result would be a considerable development of the country. Moreover, the existence of a large number of specialists (15,000) prepared to take over the leading positions in the administration and economy was intensively discussed (Pavel & Huiu, 2003). In the event that they would not be able to fulfil the promises made in the Contract with Romania, the RDC committed itself to relinquish its political power. These objectives were not fulfilled, but the RDC continued governing for the entire period of its legislative term, 1996–2000.
The conduct and the mentality of the Romanian political elites reveal the same idea as the concept defined by the Romanian philosopher C Rădulescu-Motru – ‘politicianism’, which he defined as:

disp-quote.p: … a genre of political activity, or, rather, a refined practice of political privileges, through which some of the citizens attempt and sometimes succeed in transforming the institutions and the public services from means of creating public welfare, which they should be, into means of achieving personal goals. (Rădulescu-Motru, 1904: 3)

sec.p: The elites, especially the intellectuals, argued that the society was aiming at inappropriate objectives and not at the priorities of a post-communist society. For example, a widespread idea concerned returning to the pre-Second World War Romanian social organization model, seen as the ‘golden age’ (Murgescu, 2010), although Romanian society in the last years of the 20th century consisted of other social categories and existed in a different geopolitical context. This is an argument which maintains that the elites embrace the easy option for ideas and explanations taken from other cultures or other historical periods, thus proving their inability to propose strategies of modernization in accordance with present-day social and economic realities.

The elites imposed by the new social system acted in pursuit of a new beginning, showing a tendency to deny the legacy of the former social system or political regime. This is why Romanian modernity seems to be an unfinished process. For instance, the public discourse of the elites is mainly critical of communism, although the better part of the population is faced with other social and economic problems, which affect their standard of living. This cleavage between the intellectual elites’ anticommunist discourse and present-day Romanian social reality is confirmed by a survey conducted between 22 October and 1 November 2010 by the Institute for the Investigation of Crimes of Communism and the Memory of Romanian Exile and by the Center for Opinion and Market Research, on a sample of 1123 persons aged 15 years and over. This research concluded that 83% of Romanians polled stated that they had not suffered because of communism (neither themselves, nor their families). Only 3% of the subjects mentioned that they were badly affected by communism (http://www.crimelecomunismului.ro).

Indeed, nowadays, the Romanian people have an ambivalent attitude towards the communist period and its meaning: on the one hand, the majority of the population thinks that a form of repression existed, that the communist leaders took advantage of different privileges, that the victims of the communist regime should be indemnified; on the other, many of them believe that the communist system was a positive thing and that communism stood for a good idea. Forty-four percent of the people questioned said that communism was a good idea, but a badly applied one. In addition, almost one in eight subjects considered that communism was a good idea, and that it was well applied too (http://www.crimelecomunismului.ro). Many Romanians have a lower living standard today than during the communist period.

We will not discuss here the causes that led to the fall of communism, but it has to be underlined that the transition from communism to capitalism did not lead to the affirmation of meritocracy and professional competence in society, to overcoming the lack of economic development of the socialist period or to the improvement of the standard of living, which should have been superior to what was achieved under communism. Public opinion expresses its belief that privatization, the main path of the transition to a capitalist economy, was often actually a massive theft of the public property created during the communist period, and that the new economic and financial elites were beneficiaries of the capital derived from this privatization (Pasti, 2006).

The post-communist period in Romania led to the emergence of two categories of elite: an elite with political power and an economic elite. Romania, a member of the EU, is struggling against economic chaos and against the deepening impoverishment of the population, a process opposed to the stability provided by the communist regime for the majority. Obviously, businessmen, a segment of the elite who live in the richest areas of Romanian cities, think that communism was exclusively negative, without acknowledging any of its achievements.

Although a political and legal institutional framework has been established, based mainly on European legislation and norms, I have to say that the foundations of capitalist and democratic development are still precarious in Romanian society today. One of the causes of this situation lies in the fact that there is no critical mass of reformers in society willing to devote more effort towards the construction of modernity. The political class and the intellectual elites have a modernity-oriented discourse, but they fail to create a consistent project of development and of modernization. The rapid construction of an institutional system identical with that of Western Europe was galvanized by two big national priorities: the creation of the nation-state and its independence, priorities organically dependent on a modern political and juridical system. But this modern institutional construction lacked a theoretical project, unlike the case of France, where a broad and deep spiritual and cultural movement preceded the Revolution of 1789. By contrast with other cultures, Romania proposed, most of the time, a post festum theoretical project. This means that it explained only the effects produced by a certain national or social event, but did not elaborate on a theoretical vision of the future evolution of Romanian society. Romanian culture is oriented mainly towards the past and only to a small degree is it focused on creating scenarios of future evolution. None of the important moments of modern Romanian history, including the 1989 Revolution, have been based on a theoretical project.

Romanians are influenced and shaped by their own history and social world, which continues to perpetuate mentalities and behaviors that are not compatible with the culture characteristic of European modernity. Tendential modernity expresses clearly enough the duality of people’s thinking and acting. Romanian modernity is happening as a top-down change, through institutions led by a minority educated in the spirit of modernity, which is trying to modernize a hostile or indifferent majority because modern behavior and values are not intrinsic to the lifestyle of any individual or social group. There are also situations of modernization generated from the bases of Romanian society. For instance, Romanian migration to other countries, especially to Europe, is a factor of modernization independent from the state. For the first time in their history, all Romanians are free to travel, a fact that has generated a profound revolution in their daily thinking and behavior. One-fifth of Romanian villages could be classified as ‘transnational villages’ (Sandu, 2005: 565). Another example of modernization in this sense is the increase in educational levels during the communist period. This is a very strong factor of latent modernization, with the support of state input, but with the massive participation of the population.

Modernity exists and it cannot be denied since today Romanian society is experiencing the effects of modernization: urbanization, industrialization, alphabetization, increase in educational level, democratization of the relationships between people, flexibility of the interaction between social groups. It is not modernity that is to be questioned here, but the level of modernization of all social components. Romanian modernity is characterized by ambiguity and ambivalence. The project of modernity is ambiguous, non-unitary and shot through with compromises. I would say that, because of this, Romania has modernity, but it does not have the modern man, or only to a small degree, within the urban population with its higher levels of education.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Tendential modernity is a universal phenomenon; it also appears in states with a well-structured, functional modernity. There is even a tendency to surpass the status quo, to go further towards something new in respect of the establishment. The concept of tendential modernity covers a dynamic reality, but in reality it is a continuum whose beginning and end are hard to identify. Unlike societies with a well-structured modernity due to a solid, efficient and productive economic base, it seems that the society characterized by tendential modernity will never settle. Its modernizations consist always and only of tendencies. Here, in contrast to other spaces of culture and civilization, the duration of these kinds of phenomena is much longer.

The concept I propose ensures a structured understanding of modernity in spaces where the rhythm of cultural and political modernization is faster than the slow evolution of the economy. Under these circumstances, the economy has a different specific trend, one that we call tendential modernity. Tendential modernity refers to actions and ideas concerning modernization which remain partial and not finalized. This modernity is more an aspiration, a goal to be reached, but which is never fully attained. Due to the fact that modernity is merely a tendency, never finalized, the transitions are never finished. Tendential modernity moves slowly and with difficulty through the intricate network of socio-institutional structures of the patriarchal and traditional society. It is an inlay modernity, not structured under a clear and dominant form.

I have applied my thesis to the study of the modernization of Romanian society through all its stages: the emergence of the national state, the period between the two World Wars, the communist period, and the post-communist period. Even though these periods do not have a homogeneous rate of development, I believe that tendential modernity is the essence of modern Romania’s evolutionary process. Throughout this whole period, from the late 18th century until today, cultural, political and intellectual modernization was way ahead of economic modernization because of the gap between the rate of institutional renewal and economic progress. This is why many of the modernization processes in Romania are similar to those in countries with insufficiently developed economies, a situation that can also be found in some states of the European Union. The processes of modernization are extremely diverse and the comparative analysis of some regions, like the Balkans, the ex-Soviet Union, Latin America or Asia, may reveal something specific to the modern evolution of Romania.

Tendential modernity appears in societies where social and institutional actors act in different directions and without organic adherence to a common and constant project, with the result that this project fails to become one to which local funds are directed in order to reach a dominant modernity. For instance, Romanian modernity today lacks a national development program, one that has a strategic concept – the dominant of the entire modernization project – assumed by the intellectual and political elite of Romania. This example demonstrates that modernity, as it has been developed in Western Europe, is not possible here because the institutional forms adopted from Western societies do not have the same contexts and economic conditions, and thus cannot function as they do in Western Europe. Tendential modernity exists side by side with Western reflexive modernity. Romanian modernity is mainly tendential because it has too many particularities and too few alignments with contemporary Western modernity, especially with the Western modernity of the 19th century.

Romanian society is today in another geopolitical position because of its integration into Euro-Atlantic structures. This is a position of security in respect of any threats. The circumstances of tendential modernity will persist until a wide-ranging and deep-seated process of Europeanization of all social structures takes place under the direct and indirect influence of decisions made by the EU institutions regarding the social actors and institutions of its Member-States.

I used the concept of tendential modernity to explain the theory of forms without substance (Schifirneţ, 2007a: 205). The forms without substance are systems of laws and modern institutions mechanically imported by the Romanian elites from Western societies in order to accelerate the process of social modernization, without adapting them to the historical, social and cultural particularities of the internal context. Due to this institutional mimesis, these forms or modern institutions do not prove their functionality on all levels of Romanian society. In other studies I have used the term ‘tendentious modernity’ (Schifirneţ, 2007b, 2007c, 2008, 2009a, 2009b). In this study I have adopted the term ‘tendential modernity’ because it is more appropriate to an explanation of the process of modernization in societies with a weak economy.

Here one should mention that the European Aquis is an act, initiated and determined by the Western countries, which takes a generalized view of the commonplace rights and obligations that apply to all Member-States of the EU.
